tossups.question: A word used for people who have not undergone this ritual is also used to refer to fruit harvested from a tree less than 3 years old. Muhammad claimed that Ibrahim performed this ritual on himself at age 80. Muhammad supposedly did not need to undergo this ritual, which is known as khitan (“kee-TAWN”) in Islam. The seudah (“SUE-dah”) following this ritual is obligatory, and people who refuse to attend are said to be ostracized by God. Due to concerns about (*) herpes, a variant of this ritual that involves sucking blood from a wound is no longer practiced. This ritual is performed by a mohel and is known as brit milah in Judaism. For 10 points, name this act of removing one’s foreskin.
tossups.answer: circumcision [or word forms of circumcise; accept metzitzah; accept khitan before mention; accept milah before “brit milah”]
tossups.question_sanitized: A word used for people who have not undergone this ritual is also used to refer to fruit harvested from a tree less than 3 years old. Muhammad claimed that Ibrahim performed this ritual on himself at age 80. Muhammad supposedly did not need to undergo this ritual, which is known as khitan (“kee-TAWN”) in Islam. The seudah (“SUE-dah”) following this ritual is obligatory, and people who refuse to attend are said to be ostracized by God. Due to concerns about (*) herpes, a variant of this ritual that involves sucking blood from a wound is no longer practiced. This ritual is performed by a mohel and is known as brit milah in Judaism. For 10 points, name this act of removing one’s foreskin.
tossups.answer_sanitized: circumcision [or word forms of circumcise; accept metzitzah; accept khitan before mention; accept milah before “brit milah”]

tossups.question: In one novel, this person believes that Sergey Nechayev is manipulating him into authoring a pamphlet claiming his stepson Pavel is dead. This man's brother published many of this author's works in the magazine Vremya which he was not allowed to edit officially. That magazine published many of the articles which would become this author's Diary of a Writer, including a story about two recently buried people talking, titled “Bobok”. This man is the central character of (*) J. M. Coetzee’s 1994 novel The Master of Petersburg. This man wrote about being imprisoned in Siberia in his work The House of the Dead. Sonya follows Raskolnikov to Siberia at the end of this author’s most famous novel. For 10 points, name this Russian author of The Idiot and Crime and Punishment.
tossups.question_sanitized: In one novel, this person believes that Sergey Nechayev is manipulating him into authoring a pamphlet claiming his stepson Pavel is dead. This man's brother published many of this author's works in the magazine Vremya which he was not allowed to edit officially. That magazine published many of the articles which would become this author's Diary of a Writer, including a story about two recently buried people talking, titled “Bobok”. This man is the central character of (*) J. M. Coetzee’s 1994 novel The Master of Petersburg.  This man wrote about being imprisoned in Siberia in his work The House of the Dead. Sonya follows Raskolnikov to Siberia at the end of this author’s most famous novel. For 10 points, name this Russian author of The Idiot and Crime and Punishment.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Fyodor Dostoevsky

tossups.question: At the Battle of Mobei, Wi Qing (“wee ching”) made use of a variety of these things named for Wu Gang which slowed the Xiongnu sufficiently for the Han forces to be saved by a sandstorm. Seven of these things were used by the forces of Jan Žižka (“yan JISH-ka”) at the battle of Nekmir. When used in groups during the Hussite Wars, these things came to be known as a tabor. Feigned retreats at the battle of Lippany meant that these things became less common as weapons of war. The (*) Studebaker family rose to prominence producing these things, a richly decorated variety of which are known as vardos. The Boer laager was a fortification made of these things which were made by a wainwright. For 10 points, what sort of transport was “circled” to protect against attack in the Wild West?
tossups.question_sanitized: At the Battle of Mobei, Wi Qing (“wee ching”) made use of a variety of these things named for Wu Gang which slowed the Xiongnu sufficiently for the Han forces to be saved by a sandstorm. Seven of these things were used by the forces of Jan Žižka (“yan JISH-ka”) at the battle of Nekmir. When used in groups during the Hussite Wars, these things came to be known as a tabor. Feigned retreats at the battle of Lippany meant that these things became less common as weapons of war. The (*) Studebaker family rose to prominence producing these things, a richly decorated variety of which are known as vardos. The Boer laager was a fortification made of these things which were made by a wainwright. For 10 points, what sort of transport was “circled” to protect against attack in the Wild West?
tossups.answer_sanitized: wagons

tossups.question: A song with this colour in the title repeats the line “Tell me, oh what can I do?” and may have been inspired by Astrid Kirchherr’s response to the death of Stuart Sutcliffe. A song titled for this color describes "sheets of empty canvas / untouched sheets of clay", and is one of the most popular songs on Pearl Jam's album Ten. A song with this colour in its title boasts “ / rockin' (*) John Lennon lenses, like to see ‘em spread eagle,” and was the most widely-used song for the Mannequin challenge. The biggest hit for Rae Sremmurd is titled for this colour of Beatles. For 10 points, what color is paired with yellow in a Wiz Khalifa hit adopted by Pittsburgh sports fans?

The biggest hit for Rae Sremmurd is titled for this colour of Beatles. For 10 points, what color is paired with yellow in a Wiz Khalifa hit adopted by Pittsburgh sports fans?
tossups.answer_sanitized: black [accept "Black Beatles" or "Black and Yellow"]

tossups.question: PORN syndrome is an opportunistic infection by this pathogen that was common in the height of the AIDS crisis. This pathogen is characteristically localized to a single dermatome, where it can cause persistent neuralgia (“neur-AL-gia”). Infection by either this pathogen or influenza should not be treated with aspirin to avoid Reye’s (“rye’s”) syndrome. This pathogen can cause vertigo after it spreads from the cranial nerves, as it often lies dormant in the trigeminal (“tri-GEM-in-al”) nerve. Vaccination against this pathogen is preferred to intentional (*) exposure, as it reduces the chance of reactivation into shingles that accompanies childhood infections. For 10 points, name this pathogen in the herpes family that causes itchy red bumps and is actually unrelated to its namesake bird.
tossups.answer: chicken pox [or varicella-zoster virus; accept human alphaherpesvirus-3 or HHV-3 before “herpes”; prompt on herpesvirus before “herpes”; accept herpes zoster, zosteriform pattern, or shingles before “shingles”; prompt on VZV]
tossups.question_sanitized: PORN syndrome is an opportunistic infection by this pathogen that was common in the height of the AIDS crisis. This pathogen is characteristically localized to a single dermatome, where it can cause persistent neuralgia (“neur-AL-gia”). Infection by either this pathogen or influenza should not be treated with aspirin to avoid Reye’s (“rye’s”) syndrome. This pathogen can cause vertigo after it spreads from the cranial nerves, as it often lies dormant in the trigeminal (“tri-GEM-in-al”) nerve. Vaccination against this pathogen is preferred to intentional (*) exposure, as it reduces the chance of reactivation into shingles that accompanies childhood infections. For 10 points, name this pathogen in the herpes family that causes itchy red bumps and is actually unrelated to its namesake bird.
tossups.answer_sanitized: chicken pox [or varicella-zoster virus; accept human alphaherpesvirus-3 or HHV-3 before “herpes”; prompt on herpesvirus before “herpes”; accept herpes zoster, zosteriform pattern, or shingles before “shingles”; prompt on VZV]

tossups.question: It’s not Minecraft, but this is the video game with the most runs recorded on speedrun.com (“speedrun dot com”). A $1,000 bounty was set out to recreate a glitch in this game that turned out to be due to the player’s console being hit by a cosmic ray. A YouTuber whose username is Dutch for “pancake” explained terms such as “QPU speed” and “half A-press” in a video about this game’s level “Watch for Rolling Rocks.” A seemingly-infinite (*) staircase in this game can be bypassed by backwards long-jumping. In normal play, this game requires the player to collect 70 stars in order to access the final level, “Bowser in the Sky.” For 10 points, name this first fully-3D mainline Mario game whose title features the number of bits in its console’s processing unit.
tossups.answer: Super Mario 64 [do not accept or prompt on “Super Mario 64 DS”]

tossups.answer_sanitized: Super Mario 64 [do not accept or prompt on “Super Mario 64 DS”]

tossups.question: The process of degrading “HR” examples of these things to be “LR” has a corresponding inverse approximated by the deep learning method “SR”. Small regions of these things are compared to adjacent regions in each layer of a convolutional (“convolution-al”) neural network. A lossy (“loss-y”) compression scheme for these things uses cosine functions that can produce large square artifacts and was adopted by a Joint Experts Group. The Exif (“X-if”) specification can store metadata of these files like (*) the location they were created and ISO speed. Each point in these files requires four numbers to describe the intensity and the RGB color value and is called a pixel. For 10 points, name these files which store visual information using formats like PNG (“P-N-G”) and JPEG (“j-PEG”) and are made by cameras.
tossups.answer: digital image files [or pictures; or digital photographs; accept image superresolution, high resolution images, or high-resolution images; accept JPEGs or PNGs before mentioned; prompt on files, digital data, arrays, matrices, or tensors with “what information are they storing?”]

tossups.answer_sanitized: digital image files [or pictures; or digital photographs; accept image superresolution, high resolution images, or high-resolution images; accept JPEGs or PNGs before mentioned; prompt on files, digital data, arrays, matrices, or tensors with “what information are they storing?”]

tossups.question: A Toshiba laptop is analogized to the central concept of this story in a book chapter that discusses how Gödel's (“girdle’s”) theorem cannot tell if any of the vast number of algorithms on the laptop can play chess. This story inspired a discussion of a structure named for Gregor Mendel in the Daniel Dennett book Darwin's Dangerous Idea. The narrator of this story notes that he considers the destruction wrought by the (*) Purifiers sect to be less harmful than most do because they destroyed books, which are extremely commonplace. The epigraph of this story was taken from Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy and states "By this art you may contemplate the variations of the 23 letters…" The title object of this story is composed of an indefinite number of hexagonal rooms, each with books composed of 410 pages of sequences of 25 letters. For 10 points, name this Jorge Luis Borges story about a structure named for a biblical tower.
tossups.question_sanitized: A Toshiba laptop is analogized to the central concept of this story in a book chapter that discusses how Gödel's (“girdle’s”) theorem cannot tell if any of the vast number of algorithms on the laptop can play chess. The narrator of this story notes that he considers the destruction wrought by the (*) Purifiers sect to be less harmful than most do because they destroyed books, which are extremely commonplace. The epigraph of this story was taken from Robert Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy and states "By this art you may contemplate the variations of the 23 letters…" The title object of this story is composed of an indefinite number of hexagonal rooms, each with books composed of 410 pages of sequences of 25 letters. For 10 points, name this Jorge Luis Borges story about a structure named for a biblical tower.
tossups.answer_sanitized: "The Library of Babel"

tossups.question: A ring of putti (“POOT-tee”) acts as a halo in a portrait by this artist of Jesus clutching his chest in red robes. Ernst Gombrich suggested that the presence of wasps around a sleeping man’s head in another painting represent this artist’s frequent patrons, the Vespucci family. Mars sleeps opposite Venus as satyrs play with his helmet and sword in a work completed after this artist returned from Rome to Florence. Flowers fall from (*) Chloris’s mouth as she is manhandled by a bluish-green Zephyrus in one of this artist’s mythological paintings. In another, the Hora of Spring offers a cloak to the nude title figure, who stands in a giant seashell. For 10 points, name this Renaissance artist of Primavera and The Birth of Venus.

Flowers fall from (*) Chloris’s mouth as she is manhandled by a bluish-green Zephyrus in one of this artist’s mythological paintings. In another, the Hora of Spring offers a cloak to the nude title figure, who stands in a giant seashell. For 10 points, name this Renaissance artist of Primavera and The Birth of Venus.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Sandro Botticelli

tossups.question: This general won a decisive prelude victory over the Ambrones ("AM-bro-naiss") at Aquae Sextiae. This man was given power after a catastrophic defeat by Boiorix ("BOY-oar-icks") at the Battle of Arausio. This man made a fateful decision to parade a chained enemy through the streets at his triumph, stealing the valor of one of his subordinates. After the death of his ally (*) Cinna ("SINNA"), forces loyal to this man were defeated at the Battle of the Colline Gate. This general in the Cimbrian and Jugurthine Wars required generals to provision their men and allowed landless men to be recruited into legions as part of his reforms of the Roman army. For 10 points, name this Roman general and seven-time consul, the rival of Sulla.

This general in the Cimbrian and Jugurthine Wars required generals to provision their men and allowed landless men to be recruited into legions as part of his reforms of the Roman army. For 10 points, name this Roman general and seven-time consul, the rival of Sulla.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Gaius Marius

tossups.question: They aren’t Australian Aborigines, but these people were photographed by Roland Bonaparte, the last member of the senior Bonaparte line. The Laestadianism (“le-STAH-dian-ism”) movement was a Lutheran movement which began amongst these people, who use the slogan CSV as a sun of pride. Sajos (“SIGH-yos”) is a cultural centre for these people located in one of their de facto capitals of Inari, while another parliament is located in (*) Karasjohka ("CARE-ahs-YOH-kah"). These people who sometimes live in Lavvu wear fur boots known as nutukas. A siidaat was a traditional region used by these people to demarcate reindeer herding areas. For 10 points, identify these indigenous people of northern Finland and Sweden.
tossups.answer: Sami [accept Lapps or Laplanders but inform players that those terms are now considered offensive]

tossups.answer_sanitized: Sami [accept Lapps or Laplanders but inform players that those terms are now considered offensive]

Rajah sang a Tamil adaptation of this song called “Chinna Pennana Podhile” (“CHIN-na pen-NA-na PO-delay”) for the film Aravalli. This song was used as the introduction for a show whose lead actress was signed to it (*) without her knowledge by her husband Martin Melcher. Upon hearing this song performed in a foreign embassy, a young boy screams “that’s my mother’s voice!” and is urged to whistle it as loud as he can. In The Man Who Knew Too Much, this song is performed diegetically by Doris Day. For 10 points, name this song with a grammatically-incorrect Spanish title, translated as “whatever will be, will be.”

tossups.question: This phrase titles the Nobel lecture of economist Leonid Hurwicz (“HUR-vitch”), who suggests that democratic elections or intervention can solve its namesake problem. Hurwicz also cited a discussion of this question in Plato’s Republic between Socrates and Glaucon, which centres on one group’s potential drunkenness. This phrase was originally used in a 34 line section of a text which is found in the Oxford Fragment, which discussed effeminate men or cinaedi. This phrase was originally used in a discussion of the morality of women which suggests that someone check whether eunuchs are in fact eunuchs as part of the sixth (*) satire of the Roman poet Juvenal. This phrase inspired the title of a graphic novel series by Alan Moore. For 10 points, give this phrase which asks who can provide oversight to overseers.
tossups.answer: quis custodiet ipsos custodies? [accept "who will guard the guardians themselves" or "who watches the watchers" or "who watches the watchmen"]

tossups.answer_sanitized: quis custodiet ipsos custodies? [accept "who will guard the guardians themselves" or "who watches the watchers" or "who watches the watchmen"]

tossups.question: An anthology by Richard Rorty cites Gustav Bergmann as coining a term for philosophy’s collective “turn” towards this concept. The Augustinian picture of this concept is explored in a hypothetical tribe of builders and apprentices. Saul Kripke applied the necessity of identity to this general concept by proposing rigid designators. The word (*) gavagai was invented to demonstrate this concept’s various indeterminacies in a book by W. V. O. Quine. Wittgenstein’s Philosophical Investigations demonstrates the uselessness of “private” forms of this concept with the beetle-in-a-box thought experiment. Semantics concerns the way meaning is conveyed in, for 10 points, what branch of philosophy that examines speech acts?
tossups.answer: philosophy of language [accept linguistic turn or linguistics; accept semantics before mention; prompt on meaning or definitions before mention with “what branch of philosophy concerns meaning?”]

tossups.answer_sanitized: philosophy of language [accept linguistic turn or linguistics; accept semantics before mention; prompt on meaning or definitions before mention with “what branch of philosophy concerns meaning?”]

tossups.question: Archaeologist Toribio Mejia Xesspe ("HESS-pay") was the first to systematically study these things in 1926. A museum about these things is dedicated to Dr. Maria Reiche who spread their reputation internationally. Some of these things are visible from the nearby archaeological site of Cahuachi. These things were damaged by (*) Greenpeace activists wearing improper footwear as part of a 2014 protest. Jim Woodman has proposed the theory that the people who constructed these things could have used hot air balloons, citing their technological development of puquios ("poo-KEY-ohs"). These figures were produced by removing an iron-oxide rich top layer to show the grey subsoil and are in the shape of a pelican, a whale, a monkey, and a spider. For 10 points, name these geoglyphs located in Southern Peru.

Jim Woodman has proposed the theory that the people who constructed these things could have used hot air balloons, citing their technological development of puquios ("poo-KEY-ohs"). These figures were produced by removing an iron-oxide rich top layer to show the grey subsoil and are in the shape of a pelican, a whale, a monkey, and a spider. For 10 points, name these geoglyphs located in Southern Peru.
tossups.answer_sanitized: Nazca lines

tossups.question: In the First Quarto, this character was given a name meaning "tedious repetition." This character advises to spend a lot on fine but unfancy clothes in a speech where this character says to "Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice." Gertrude exclaims "Oh, what a rash and bloody deed is this!" after the death of this character. tossups.answer_sanitized: Polonius [accept Corambis]

tossups.question: Uranium binds two rings with this many carbons in uranocene (“urano-scene”), the most common molecule with dihedral symmetry of this order. The somewhat barrel-shaped barrelene has this many carbons and can be formed from the Diels-Alder (“DEALS-all-der”) reaction between benzene and acetylene (“a-SEE-till-ene”). tossups.question: Erika Aittamaa was known for producing these items which were known in Sweden as Lovikkavante. Cornelia James has a royal warrant for producing these goods. Ambrose Bierce described one sort of this item of clothing as “a mighty poor way to spell musketeer” in his Devil’s Dictionary. On the song “Stronger,” Kanye West mentions these products produced by Isotoner which gained notoriety in the 1990s. Elementary school teacher Jen Ellis received orders to make hundreds of these items and was forced to work with the (*) Vermont Teddy Bear Company to match demand after Bernie Sanders was snapped wearing some of these items she had knitted. For 10 points, name these common items of clothing worn on the hands which can be “fingerless.”

On the song “Stronger,” Kanye West mentions these products produced by Isotoner which gained notoriety in the 1990s. Elementary school teacher Jen Ellis received orders to make hundreds of these items and was forced to work with the (*) Vermont Teddy Bear Company to match demand after Bernie Sanders was snapped wearing some of these items she had knitted. For 10 points, name these common items of clothing worn on the hands which can be “fingerless.”
tossups.answer_sanitized: gloves [accept mittens, mousquetaires, or other equivalents]

tossups.question: In 1970, George Rawlings and Ray Garland were defeated by an independent candidate in this state’s 1970 senate election. James Thomson worked with his brother-in-law, a senator from this state, to circumvent Supreme Court rulings via the Stanley Plan. A senator from this state split with the government of President Thomas Jefferson as leader of the Tertium Quids who promoted the Principles of ’98. The election of Republican governor Abner Holton marked the demise of its (*) Byrd Organization which had dominated its elections in the early 20th century. This state was represented in the Senate by John Randolph of Roanoke. For 10 points, James Monroe and John Tyler both represented what state in the senate, nicknamed the “Mother of Presidents?”

This state was represented in the Senate by John Randolph of Roanoke. For 10 points, James Monroe and John Tyler both represented what state in the senate, nicknamed the “Mother of Presidents?”
tossups.answer_sanitized: Virginia
